Diachasma alloeum is a species of parasitoid wasp that belongs to the family Braconidae. Parasitoid wasps are insects that lay their eggs inside or on the body of other insects, and the wasp larvae then feed on and eventually kill the host.

D. alloeum is a small wasp, typically measuring around 3-5 millimeters in length. It has a slender body, long antennae, and a distinct ovipositor (egg-laying structure) at the tip of its abdomen. The coloration of D. alloeum is generally dark, with a black or dark brown head and thorax, and a black or dark brown abdomen.

These wasps are known to parasitize the larvae of various fruit fly species, including the economically important olive fruit fly (Bactrocera oleae) and the Mediterranean fruit fly (Ceratitis capitata). The female wasp locates the host larvae, typically found within fruits, and inserts her ovipositor to lay her eggs inside the host. The wasp larvae then develop within the host, eventually emerging and killing the host.

D. alloeum is considered an important biological control agent, as it can help regulate the populations of various fruit fly pests, which can have significant agricultural and economic impacts. The study of this species and its interactions with host insects is an important area of research in the field of entomology and pest management.
